   60 year old man with history of hepatitis C (s/p interferon rx with no
   response), cirrhosis, esophageal varices and hyponatremia admitted with
   dyspnea and diffuse abdominal pain, found to have peritonitis as well
   as a possibility of CAP.
   .
   Sepsis: Suspect sepsis is due to SBP as below, also possibly due to
   pna. Will treat with abx as outlined below, pressors and IVF bolus to
   support BP. Mixed venous O2 sat in ED was 91%, so pRBCs were not
   administered, however hematocrit on admission
   was ~21, and pt was transfused. Hypothermia (current temp 95 with bear
   hugger), hyponatremia, hyperkalemia and hypoglycemia consistent with
   sepsis, but also concerning for adrenal insufficiency. Pt has not
   recently been on steroids and has no other RF for adrenal
   insufficiency.  BCx grew Clostridium Perfringens [**12-13**].  d/c
   cisatracurium.
   - CT abdomen to r/o perforation, as patient stable to go for scan today
   - Continuing Zosyn/Clinda/Micafungin per ID recs; dc
ed Vanc
   - Norepinephrine to titrate to MAP>60; vasopression dc
   - Monitor CVP (goal [**10-19**]) and SvO2 (goal>70%)
   - [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim test without appropriate increase in cortisol; however,
   will hold off on steroids for now.
   .
   Peritonitis: ?SBP but without positive cultures.  Abdominal pain,
   prominent neutrophilia on ascitic fluid diff (17,000 WBC, 87% neuts)
   and significant left-shift on CBC with diff (33% bands) in the setting
   of a history of variceal bleeding are all consistent with SBP. Normally
   would treat with ceftriaxone, but given additional concerns for
   pneumonia will treat with cipro, pip-tazo and vancomycin. Hepatobiliary
   sx recs ([**12-15**]): recommend re-tapping him today.  If his WBC is still
   very high, he may need to be explored.  WBC high but improved from
   prior, obtaining CT scan to further evaluate, as outlined above.
   - Continue Zosyn/Clinda/Micafungin per ID recs
   - f/u GI/Liver recs
   - Albumin 1.5g/kg on day 1 (125g) and 1g/kg (75) on day 3 ([**12-17**]).
   - General surgery c/s for possible exploration, note pending
   .
   Dyspnea/Respiratory Failure: Pt was intubated in the ED given
   hypotension, concern for developing respiratory failure given
   tachypnea. ABG in MICU indicates elevated PaO2 on current ventilator
   settings.  The differential for the pt's dyspnea includes pneumonia,
   influenza, ascites or CHF. The pt had a left shift on CBC with diff and
   his girlfriend reported that he recently had a "respiratory infection"
   which raises concern for a post-viral pna or bacterial pna. Initial
   read of CXR raised concern for R LL infiltrate, however on final read
   there is no mention of an opacity. Tachypnea likely secondary to
   acidosis.  Also evidence of volume overload and CHF given edema, CXR
   consistent with fluid overload, and elevated CVP.
   - Consider Lasix diuresis tomorrow or later tonight following CT scan
   for volume overload and pulmonary edema
   - Maintain on ventilator;  Decrease FiO2 from 50% to 40%, increase PEEP
   from 10 to 12 to facilitate this.
   - ABG and lactate [**Hospital1 **] (lactate down-trending now)
   - Sedation with Fentanyl and Midazolam gtt
   - f/u sputum culture
   .
   Epistaxis:  ENT consulted, patient s/p bilateral packing.
   - f/u ENT recs; packing removed yesterday. Remainder of packing to be
   removed [**12-18**].
   .
   Anemia: Pt's recent baseline hematocrit appears to be ~25-30, and was
   21 on admission. Pt was noted to be guaiac positive on exam in ED, and
   had frank blood in NGT. Suspect that pt has chronic macrocytic anemia
   secondary to liver disease, with superimposed acute blood loss anemia
   from variceal bleed or bleeding ulcer. No schistocytes on smear to
   indicate hemolysis, however INR more elevated than in the past, and
   thrombocytopenia is more pronounced. GI did an EGD to evaluate for UGIB
   cause and no bleeding source was found.  Pt was on pantoprazole bolus
   and octreotide gtt for likely variceal bleeding: d/c
d now as HCT
   stable.
   - Continue IV PPI [**Hospital1 **]
   - Daily coags and CBC; Transfuse as needed for falling Hct.
   .
   Hepatitis C Cirrhosis: MELD on admission was 27, discriminate function
   was 61. On exam pt is jaundiced. LFT's similar to prior LFT's with the
   exception of bili, which is markedly elevated at 18. Reportedly the pt
   stopped drinking EtOH in [**Month (only) 11**]. Serum EtOH was negative.
   - Hepatology will follow patient
   - Hold lactulose, rifaximin for now, restart when PO's okay
   - Hold nadolol for now given hypotension, pressor requirement
   .
   Less Active Issues
   .
   Thrombocytopenia: Currently plts are 34, which is below baseline.
   Suspect that thrombocytopenia is due to poor synthetic function in the
   setting of liver disease. Pt has chronic epistaxis. Hemolysis is less
   likely.  Smear showed: no schistocytes, a few large platelets but many
   small platelets.  Likely bone marrow difficulty with production at the
   same time as it tries to increase production in the setting of platelet
   destruction.
   - Trend plts daily
   - Avoid heparin products in the setting of plt<100, GIB
   .
   Non-anion gap Metabolic Acidosis: pH on ABG 7.29. Pt has a normal anion
   gap in the setting of chronic hyponatremia. Suspect acidosis is
   secondary to lactic acidosis in the setting of sepsis, SBP.  s/p 2
   units PRBC transfusion.
   - frequent ABG's
   - hold maintenance fluids to avoid worsening of acidosis
   - add on alk phos and CEA to ascitic fluid analysis given GI/Liver
   service's concern for perforation
   - f/u renal recs, likely no need for HD now
   .
   Acute Renal Failure:  Patient
s acute renal failure likely [**2-9**] sepsis,
   monitor. F/u renal recs.
   - Now resolved.
   .
   FEN: Bolus IVF prn, replete electrolytes
   Prophylaxis: pneumoboots

   Son [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 5320**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9701**]
   .

Summary:

The patient is a 60-year-old male with a history of hepatitis C cirrhosis, esophageal varices, and hyponatremia, admitted with dyspnea and diffuse abdominal pain. He was found to have peritonitis and a possibility of CAP. The patient was intubated in the ED due to hypotension and concern for developing respiratory failure. He has a high WBC count, neutrophilia, and a left shift on CBC with diff, consistent with sepsis. The patient was treated with antibiotics, pressors, and IV fluids to support his blood pressure.

The patient has several medical complications, including:

* Sepsis without organ dysfunction
* Peritonitis, spontaneous bacterial (SBP)
* Anemia, chronic and acute
* Thrombocytopenia, chronic
* Cirrhosis of the liver
* Hepatitis, other
* Acidosis, metabolic
* Respiratory failure
* Epistaxis
* Non-anion gap metabolic acidosis
* Acute renal failure

The patient is currently in the ICU and is being treated with antibiotics, pressors, and IV fluids. He is also receiving oxygen therapy and is being monitored for respiratory failure.

Potential medical complications that can arise:

* Worsening of sepsis and organ dysfunction
* Development of organ failure, such as respiratory or renal failure
* Hemorrhage or bleeding complications due to thrombocytopenia
* Hepatic encephalopathy or liver failure
* Acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease
* Pneumonia or other secondary infections
* Cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or cardiac failure
* Gastrointestinal complications, such as bleeding or perforation

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment accordingly to prevent or manage these potential complications.

   60 year old man with history of hepatitis C (s/p interferon rx with no
   response), cirrhosis, esophageal varices and hyponatremia admitted with
   dyspnea and diffuse abdominal pain, found to have peritonitis as well
   as a possibility of CAP.
   .
   Sepsis: Suspect sepsis is due to SBP as below, also possibly due to
   pna. Will treat with abx as outlined below, pressors and IVF bolus to
   support BP. Mixed venous O2 sat in ED was 91%, so pRBCs were not
   administered, however hematocrit on admission
   was ~21, and pt was transfused. Hypothermia (current temp 95 with bear
   hugger), hyponatremia, hyperkalemia and hypoglycemia consistent with
   sepsis, but also concerning for adrenal insufficiency. Pt has not
   recently been on steroids and has no other RF for adrenal
   insufficiency.  BCx grew Clostridium Perfringens [**12-13**].  d/c
   cisatracurium. s/p CT abdomen on [**12-17**].
   - Continuing Zosyn & Micafungin per ID recs; dc
ed Vanc and clindamycin
   - Norepinephrine to titrate to MAP>60; vasopression dc
   - Monitor CVP (goal [**10-19**]) and SvO2 (goal>70%)
   - [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim test without appropriate increase in cortisol; start
   Hydrocort IV 50mg q6h today ([**12-18**])
   .
   Peritonitis: ?SBP but without positive cultures.  Abdominal pain,
   prominent neutrophilia on ascitic fluid diff (17,000 WBC, 87% neuts)
   and significant left-shift on CBC with diff (33% bands) in the setting
   of a history of variceal bleeding are all consistent with SBP. Normally
   would treat with ceftriaxone, but given additional concerns for
   pneumonia will treat with cipro, pip-tazo and vancomycin. Hepatobiliary
   sx recs ([**12-15**]): recommend re-tapping him today.  If his WBC is still
   very high, he may need to be explored.  WBC high but improved from
   prior, obtaining CT scan to further evaluate, as outlined above.
   - Continue Zosyn/Clinda/Micafungin per ID recs
   - f/u GI/Liver recs
   - f/u general surgery recs
   .
   Dyspnea/Respiratory Failure: Pt was intubated in the ED given
   hypotension, concern for developing respiratory failure given
   tachypnea. ABG in MICU indicates elevated PaO2 on current ventilator
   settings.  The differential for the pt's dyspnea includes pneumonia,
   influenza, ascites or CHF. The pt had a left shift on CBC with diff and
   his girlfriend reported that he recently had a "respiratory infection"
   which raises concern for a post-viral pna or bacterial pna. Initial
   read of CXR raised concern for R LL infiltrate, however on final read
   there is no mention of an opacity. Tachypnea likely secondary to
   acidosis.  Also evidence of volume overload and CHF given edema, CXR
   consistent with fluid overload, and elevated CVP.
   - Consider Lasix diuresis tomorrow for volume overload, hold for now
   given had IV contrast dye load from CT scan on [**12-17**] so want to protect
   kidneys
   - Maintain on ventilator; Decrease FiO2, keep PEEP steady as given
   abdominal distention feel he needs this PEEP level.
   - ABG and lactate daily (lactate down-trending now)
   - Change from fentanyl and midazolam (concern with ARF that these
   medications are going to not be cleared for a while and may potentiate
   AMS as well as ileus); change to propofol
   - f/u sputum culture
   .
   Epistaxis:  ENT consulted, patient s/p bilateral packing.
   - f/u ENT recs
   - Give FFP prior to packing removal today ([**12-18**]) by ENT
   .
   Anemia: Pt's recent baseline hematocrit appears to be ~25-30, and was
   21 on admission. Pt was noted to be guaiac positive on exam in ED, and
   had frank blood in NGT. Suspect that pt has chronic macrocytic anemia
   secondary to liver disease, with superimposed acute blood loss anemia
   from variceal bleed or bleeding ulcer. No schistocytes on smear to
   indicate hemolysis, however INR more elevated than in the past, and
   thrombocytopenia is more pronounced. GI did an EGD to evaluate for UGIB
   cause and no bleeding source was found.  Pt was on pantoprazole bolus
   and octreotide gtt for likely variceal bleeding: d/c
d now as HCT
   stable.
   - Continue IV PPI [**Hospital1 **]
   - Daily coags and CBC; Transfuse as needed for falling Hct.
   .
   Hepatitis C Cirrhosis: MELD on admission was 27, discriminate function
   was 61. On exam pt is jaundiced. LFT's similar to prior LFT's with the
   exception of bili, which is markedly elevated at 18. Reportedly the pt
   stopped drinking EtOH in [**Month (only) 11**]. Serum EtOH was negative.
   - Hepatology will follow patient
   - Hold lactulose, rifaximin for now, restart when PO's okay
   - Hold nadolol for now given hypotension, pressor requirement
   .
   Less Active Issues
   .
   Thrombocytopenia: Currently plts are 34, which is below baseline.
   Suspect that thrombocytopenia is due to poor synthetic function in the
   setting of liver disease. Pt has chronic epistaxis. Hemolysis is less
   likely.  Smear showed: no schistocytes, a few large platelets but many
   small platelets.  Likely bone marrow difficulty with production at the
   same time as it tries to increase production in the setting of platelet
   destruction.
   - Trend plts daily
   - Avoid heparin products in the setting of plt<100, GIB
   .
   Non-anion gap Metabolic Acidosis: Resolved. pH on ABG 7.29. Pt has a
   normal anion gap in the setting of chronic hyponatremia. Suspect
   acidosis is secondary to lactic acidosis in the setting of sepsis,
   SBP.  s/p 2 units PRBC transfusion.
   - frequent ABG's
   - hold maintenance fluids to avoid worsening of acidosis
   - add on alk phos and CEA to ascitic fluid analysis given GI/Liver
   service's concern for perforation
   - f/u renal recs, likely no need for HD now
   .
   Acute Renal Failure:  Patient
s acute renal failure likely [**2-9**] sepsis,
   monitor. F/u renal recs.
   - Now resolved.
   - s/p IV contrast dye load on [**12-17**], watch Cr and hold on diuresis.
   .
   FEN: Hold on IVF today given peripheral edema, replete electrolytes
   Prophylaxis: pneumoboots
   Access: R and L 20-g PIVs, R triple-lumen IJ, a-line
   Code:  Full (discussed with girlfriend)
   Communication: [**Name (NI) **] GF and son

   Son [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 5320**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9701**]
   .
   Disposition: pending clinical improvement, ICU for now

Summary:

The patient is a 60-year-old man with a history of hepatitis C, cirrhosis, and esophageal varices who was admitted with dyspnea and diffuse abdominal pain. He was found to have peritonitis, possibly due to spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP), and sepsis. He has been treated with antibiotics, pressors, and IV fluids to support his blood pressure. He has also been intubated due to respiratory failure. His laboratory results show anemia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated liver enzymes. He has a history of variceal bleeding and is at risk for further bleeding.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is likely due to SBP, but it is also possible that it is caused by pneumonia. He is at risk for further complications, such as organ dysfunction and death.
2. Peritonitis: The patient's peritonitis is likely due to SBP, but it is also possible that it is caused by another bacterial infection. He is at risk for further complications, such as abscesses and sepsis.
3. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely due to chronic macrocytic anemia secondary to liver disease, with superimposed acute blood loss anemia from variceal bleeding or bleeding ulcer.
4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia is likely due to poor synthetic function in the setting of liver disease. He is at risk for further bleeding complications.
5. Hepatic Encephalopathy: The patient's liver disease is likely causing encephalopathy, which is a complication of liver disease characterized by altered mental status, confusion, and disorientation.
6. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to pneumonia, sepsis, and acidosis. He is at risk for further complications, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia and respiratory failure.
7. Cardiac Complications: The patient's cardiac status is likely compromised due to his liver disease, sepsis, and acidosis. He is at risk for further complications, such as cardiac arrest and heart failure.
8. Renal Complications: The patient's acute renal failure is likely due to sepsis and acidosis. He is at risk for further complications, such as chronic kidney disease and end-stage renal disease.
9. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's gastrointestinal status is likely compromised due to his liver disease, sepsis, and acidosis. He is at risk for further complications, such as gastrointestinal bleeding, perforation, and sepsis.

Recommendations:

1. Continue antibiotics and pressors to treat sepsis and peritonitis.
2. Monitor the patient's anemia and thrombocytopenia closely and transfuse as needed.
3. Continue to manage the patient's respiratory failure with mechanical ventilation and adjust the ventilator settings as needed.
4. Monitor the patient's cardiac status closely and adjust the pressors and fluids as needed.
5. Monitor the patient's renal status closely and adjust the fluids and diuretics as needed.
6. Monitor the patient's gastrointestinal status closely and adjust the fluids and medications as needed.
7. Consider referring the patient to a liver transplant center for further evaluation and treatment.
8. Consider referring the patient to a nephrologist for further evaluation and treatment of his acute renal failure.
9. Consider referring the patient to a pulmonologist for further evaluation and treatment of his respiratory failure.

Summary:

The patient is a 60-year-old man with HCV cirrhosis who is critically ill with septic shock, peritonitis, and respiratory failure. He is on mechanical ventilation with a PEEP of 12 cmH2O and an FiO2 of 60%. He has a history of chronic anemia, acute anemia secondary to blood loss, chronic thrombocytopenia, cirrhosis of the liver, and hepatitis. He has a CTA abdomen that showed no evidence of bowel pathology, but a stenosis of the celiac artery was detected.

The patient's vital signs are:

* T: 36.1°C
* HR: 83 bpm
* BP: 108/53 mmHg
* RR: 16 breaths/min
* SpO2: 96%

He is receiving levophed, fentanyl, and norepinephrine infusions. He has a central venous catheter, an arterial line, and a multi-lumen line. He is on prophylactic medications for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP.

Potential medical complications:

1. Septic shock: The patient's septic shock is likely to worsen if not properly managed. He requires close monitoring of his vital signs, and his antibiotic regimen should be reassessed to ensure that it is effective against the causative organisms.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely to worsen if his PEEP is not weaned off gradually. He requires close monitoring of his oxygen saturation and respiratory rate.
3. Acute renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure is likely to worsen if he is not managed properly. He requires close monitoring of his creatinine levels, and his fluid balance should be carefully managed to prevent further deterioration.
4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia is likely to worsen if not managed properly. He requires close monitoring of his platelet count, and his bleeding risk should be assessed regularly.
5. Liver failure: The patient's liver failure is likely to worsen if not managed properly. He requires close monitoring of his liver enzymes, and his coagulation profile should be carefully managed to prevent further deterioration.

Overall, the patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications.

   60 year old man with history of hepatitis C (s/p interferon rx with no
   response), cirrhosis, esophageal varices and hyponatremia admitted with
   dyspnea and diffuse abdominal pain, found to have peritonitis as well
   as a possibility of CAP.
   .
   Sepsis: Suspect sepsis is due to SBP as below, also possibly due to
   pna. Will treat with abx as outlined below, pressors and IVF bolus to
   support BP. Mixed venous O2 sat in ED was 91%, so pRBCs were not
   administered, however hematocrit on admission
   was ~21, and pt was transfused. Hypothermia (current temp 95 with bear
   hugger), hyponatremia, hyperkalemia and hypoglycemia consistent with
   sepsis, but also concerning for adrenal insufficiency. Pt has not
   recently been on steroids and has no other RF for adrenal
   insufficiency.  BCx grew Clostridium Perfringens [**12-13**].  d/c
   cisatracurium. s/p CT abdomen on [**12-17**].
   - Continuing Zosyn & Micafungin per ID recs; dc
ed Vanc and clindamycin
   - Norepinephrine to titrate to MAP>60; vasopression dc
 pressors
   off
   - Monitor CVP (goal [**10-19**]) and SvO2 (goal>70%)
   - [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim test without appropriate increase in cortisol; start
   Hydrocort IV 50mg q6h today ([**12-18**])
   .
   Peritonitis: ?SBP but without positive cultures.  Abdominal pain,
   prominent neutrophilia on ascitic fluid diff (17,000 WBC, 87% neuts)
   and significant left-shift on CBC with diff (33% bands) in the setting
   of a history of variceal bleeding are all consistent with SBP. Normally
   would treat with ceftriaxone, but given additional concerns for
   pneumonia will treat with cipro, pip-tazo and vancomycin. Hepatobiliary
   sx recs ([**12-15**]): recommend re-tapping him today.  If his WBC is still
   very high, he may need to be explored.  WBC high but improved from
   prior, obtaining CT scan to further evaluate, as outlined above.
   - Continue Zosyn /Micafungin per ID recs
   - f/u GI/Liver recs
   - f/u general surgery recs
   .
   Dyspnea/Respiratory Failure: Pt was intubated in the ED given
   hypotension, concern for developing respiratory failure given
   tachypnea. ABG in MICU indicates elevated PaO2 on current ventilator
   settings.  The differential for the pt's dyspnea includes pneumonia,
   influenza, ascites or CHF. The pt had a left shift on CBC with diff and
   his girlfriend reported that he recently had a "respiratory infection"
   which raises concern for a post-viral pna or bacterial pna. Initial
   read of CXR raised concern for R LL infiltrate, however on final read
   there is no mention of an opacity. Tachypnea likely secondary to
   acidosis.  Also evidence of volume overload and CHF given edema, CXR
   consistent with fluid overload, and elevated CVP.
   - hold for diuresis for now given had IV contrast dye load from CT scan
   on [**12-17**] and has incr Cr over last 2 days
   -  Maintain on ventilator; Decrease FiO2, try to increase PEEP as given
   abdominal distention feel he needs a lot of PEEP.
   - Place esophageal balloon
   - ABG and lactate daily (lactate down-trending now)
   - All sedation off x 24 hours on [**12-19**]
   - f/u sputum culture
   .
   Acute Renal Failure:  Patient initially had elevated Cr, thought to be
   due to sepsis which resolved).  Pt
s creatinine has been rising again x
   2 days (during this hospitalization, Cr 1.7 -> 0.8 -> today 1.5
   [**12-19**]).  ARF most likely due to aggressive diuresis in last several
   days plus IV contrast load for CT abd.  However, hepatorenal syndrome
   is also a possibility.
   - F/u renal/hepatology recs.
   - will give IV albumin 1g/kg.
   - monitor UOP closely
   .
   Altered mental status: Pt is still with decreased mental status despite
   being off of sedation x 1 day on [**12-19**]. Neurologic exam difficult, but
   no obvious deficit. The most likely etiology at this point is stage 4
   hepatic encephalopathy, given patient
s severe liver disease and rising
   bilirubin.
   - Restart lactulose today.  Titrate to 3 BMs daily.
   - Can add back Rifaxamin if no improvement with lactulose alone.
   - Can consider head CT, and additional AMS w/u if no improvement with
   tx of hepatic encephalopathy.
   .
   Epistaxis:  ENT consulted, patient s/p bilateral packing.
   - f/u ENT recs
   - cont Epistaxis precautions
   .
   Anemia: Pt's recent baseline hematocrit appears to be ~25-30, and was
   21 on admission. Pt was noted to be guaiac positive on exam in ED, and
   had frank blood in NGT. Suspect that pt has chronic macrocytic anemia
   secondary to liver disease, with superimposed acute blood loss anemia
   from variceal bleed or bleeding ulcer. No schistocytes on smear to
   indicate hemolysis, however INR more elevated than in the past, and
   thrombocytopenia is more pronounced. GI did an EGD to evaluate for UGIB
   cause and no bleeding source was found.  Pt was on pantoprazole bolus
   and octreotide gtt for likely variceal bleeding: d/c
d now as HCT
   stable.
   - Continue IV PPI [**Hospital1 **]
   - Daily coags and CBC; Transfuse as needed for falling Hct.
   .
   Hepatitis C Cirrhosis: MELD on admission was 27, discriminate function
   was 61. On exam pt is jaundiced. LFT's similar to prior LFT's with the
   exception of bili, which is markedly elevated at 18. Reportedly the pt
   stopped drinking EtOH in [**Month (only) 11**]. Serum EtOH was negative.
   - F/u Hepatology recs
   - Restarting lactulose today
   - Hold nadolol for now given hypotension, pressor requirement
   .
   Less Active Issues
   .
   Thrombocytopenia: Currently plts are 34, which is below baseline.
   Suspect that thrombocytopenia is due to poor synthetic function in the
   setting of liver disease. Pt has chronic epistaxis. Hemolysis is less
   likely.  Smear showed: no schistocytes, a few large platelets but many
   small platelets.  Likely bone marrow difficulty with production at the
   same time as it tries to increase production in the setting of platelet
   destruction.
   - Trend plts daily
   - Avoid heparin products in the setting of plt<100, GIB
   .
   Non-anion gap Metabolic Acidosis: Resolved. pH on ABG 7.29. Pt has a
   normal anion gap in the setting of chronic hyponatremia. Suspect
   acidosis is secondary to lactic acidosis in the setting of sepsis,
   SBP.  s/p 2 units PRBC transfusion.
   - frequent ABG's
   - hold maintenance fluids to avoid worsening of acidosis
   - add on alk phos and CEA to ascitic fluid analysis given GI/Liver
   service's concern for perforation
   - f/u renal recs, likely no need for HD now
   .
   FEN: Hold on IVF today given peripheral edema, replete electrolytes
   Prophylaxis: pneumoboots
   Access: R and L 20-g PIVs, R triple-lumen IJ, a-line
   Code:  Full (discussed with girlfriend)
   Communication: [**Name (NI) **] GF and son
   Contact Info: Girlfriend [**Name (NI) 105**] [**Name (NI) 1309**]  cell: [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9699**] home: [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9771**]
   Son [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 5320**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9701**]
   .
   Disposition: pending clinical improvement, ICU for now

   - Continuing Zosyn & Micafungin per ID recs; dc
ed Vanc and clindamycin
   - Norepinephrine to titrate to MAP>60; vasopression dc
 pressors
   off
   - Monitor CVP (goal [**10-19**]) and SvO2 (goal>70%)
   - [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim test without appropriate increase in cortisol; start
   Hydrocort IV 50mg q6h today ([**12-18**])
   .
   Peritonitis: ?SBP but without positive cultures.  Abdominal pain,
   prominent neutrophilia on ascitic fluid diff (17,000 WBC, 87% neuts)
   and significant left-shift on CBC with diff (33% bands) in the setting
   of a history of variceal bleeding are all consistent with SBP. Normally
   would treat with ceftriaxone, but given additional concerns for
   pneumonia will treat with cipro, pip-tazo and vancomycin. Hepatobiliary
   sx recs ([**12-15**]): recommend re-tapping him today.  If his WBC is still
   very high, he may need to be explored.  WBC high but improved from
   prior, obtaining CT scan to further evaluate, as outlined above.
   - Continue Zosyn /Micafungin per ID recs
   - f/u GI/Liver recs
   - f/u general surgery recs
   .
   Dyspnea/Respiratory Failure: Pt was intubated in the ED given
   hypotension, concern for developing respiratory failure given
   tachypnea. ABG in MICU indicates elevated PaO2 on current ventilator
   settings.  The differential for the pt's dyspnea includes pneumonia,
   influenza, ascites or CHF. The pt had a left shift on CBC with diff and
   his girlfriend reported that he recently had a "respiratory infection"
   which raises concern for a post-viral pna or bacterial pna. Initial
   read of CXR raised concern for R LL infiltrate, however on final read
   there is no mention of an opacity. Tachypnea likely secondary to
   acidosis.  Also evidence of volume overload and CHF given edema, CXR
   consistent with fluid overload, and elevated CVP.
   - hold for diuresis for now given had IV contrast dye load from CT scan
   on [**12-17**] and has incr Cr over last 2 days
   -  Maintain on ventilator; Decrease FiO2, try to increase PEEP as given
   abdominal distention feel he needs a lot of PEEP.
   - Place esophageal balloon
   - ABG and lactate daily (lactate down-trending now)
   - All sedation off x 24 hours on [**12-19**]
   - f/u sputum culture
   .
   Acute Renal Failure:  Patient initially had elevated Cr, thought to be
   due to sepsis which resolved).  Pt
s creatinine has been rising again x
   2 days (during this hospitalization, Cr 1.7 -> 0.8 -> today 1.5
   [**12-19**]).  ARF most likely due to aggressive diuresis in last several
   days plus IV contrast load for CT abd.  However, hepatorenal syndrome
   is also a possibility.
   - F/u renal/hepatology recs.
   - will give IV albumin 1g/kg.
   - monitor UOP closely
   .
   Altered mental status: Pt is still with decreased mental status despite
   being off of sedation x 1 day on [**12-19**]. Neurologic exam difficult, but
   no obvious deficit. The most likely etiology at this point is stage 4
   hepatic encephalopathy, given patient
s severe liver disease and rising
   bilirubin.
   - Restart lactulose today.  Titrate to 3 BMs daily.
   - Can add back Rifaxamin if no improvement with lactulose alone.
   - Can consider head CT, and additional AMS w/u if no improvement with
   tx of hepatic encephalopathy.
   .
   Epistaxis:  ENT consulted, patient s/p bilateral packing.
   - f/u ENT recs
   - cont Epistaxis precautions
   .
   Anemia: Pt's recent baseline hematocrit appears to be ~25-30, and was
   21 on admission. Pt was noted to be guaiac positive on exam in ED, and
   had frank blood in NGT. Suspect that pt has chronic macrocytic anemia
   secondary to liver disease, with superimposed acute blood loss anemia
   from variceal bleed or bleeding ulcer. No schistocytes on smear to
   indicate hemolysis, however INR more elevated than in the past, and
   thrombocytopenia is more pronounced. GI did an EGD to evaluate for UGIB
   cause and no bleeding source was found.  Pt was on pantoprazole bolus
   and octreotide gtt for likely variceal bleeding: d/c
d now as HCT
   stable.
   - Continue IV PPI [**Hospital1 **]
   - Daily coags and CBC; Transfuse as needed for falling Hct.
   .
   Hepatitis C Cirrhosis: MELD on admission was 27, discriminate function
   was 61. On exam pt is jaundiced. LFT's similar to prior LFT's with the
   exception of bili, which is markedly elevated at 18. Reportedly the pt
   stopped drinking EtOH in [**Month (only) 11**]. Serum EtOH was negative.
   - F/u Hepatology recs
   - Restarting lactulose today
   - Hold nadolol for now given hypotension, pressor requirement
   .
   Less Active Issues
   .
   Thrombocytopenia: Currently plts are 34, which is below baseline.
   Suspect that thrombocytopenia is due to poor synthetic function in the
   setting of liver disease. Pt has chronic epistaxis. Hemolysis is less
   likely.  Smear showed: no schistocytes, a few large platelets but many
   small platelets.  Likely bone marrow difficulty with production at the
   same time as it tries to increase production in the setting of platelet
   destruction.
   - Trend plts daily
   - Avoid heparin products in the setting of plt<100, GIB
   .
   Non-anion gap Metabolic Acidosis: Resolved. pH on ABG 7.29. Pt has a
   normal anion gap in the setting of chronic hyponatremia. Suspect
   acidosis is secondary to lactic acidosis in the setting of sepsis,
   SBP.  s/p 2 units PRBC transfusion.
   - frequent ABG's
   - hold maintenance fluids to avoid worsening of acidosis
   - add on alk phos and CEA to ascitic fluid analysis given GI/Liver
   service's concern for perforation
   - f/u renal recs, likely no need for HD now
   .
   FEN: Hold on IVF today given peripheral edema, replete electrolytes
   Prophylaxis: pneumoboots

Based on the patient's progress note, the following medical complications can arise:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is already intubated and on ventilator support due to respiratory failure. The risk of developing further respiratory complications, such as pneumonia or ARDS, is high.
2. Sepsis: The patient has sepsis due to spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) and possibly also due to pneumonia. The risk of developing further septic complications, such as organ dysfunction or death, is high.
3. Acute Renal Failure (ARF): The patient's creatinine levels are rising, and ARF is likely due to aggressive diuresis and IV contrast load. The risk of developing further renal complications, such as end-stage renal disease, is high.
4. Altered Mental Status: The patient has decreased mental status, which may be due to stage 4 hepatic encephalopathy. The risk of developing further neurological complications, such as seizures or coma, is high.
5. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is low, which may be due to liver disease, sepsis, or bleeding. The risk of developing further bleeding complications is high.
6. Hepatitis C Cirrhosis: The patient has cirrhosis due to hepatitis C, which may lead to further complications, such as liver failure, portal hypertension, or esophageal varices.
7. Non-anion gap Metabolic Acidosis: The patient has metabolic acidosis, which may be due to lactic acidosis in the setting of sepsis and SBP. The risk of developing further acidosis complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias or seizures, is high.
8. Fluid Overload: The patient has fluid overload, which may lead to further complications, such as pulmonary edema, cardiac failure, or renal failure.

The patient's current condition is critical, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent or mitigate these potential complications.

   60 year old man with history of hepatitis C (s/p interferon rx with no
   response), cirrhosis, esophageal varices and hyponatremia admitted with
   dyspnea and diffuse abdominal pain, found to have peritonitis as well
   as a possibility of CAP.
   .
   Sepsis: Suspect sepsis is due to SBP as below, also possibly due to
   pna. Will treat with abx as outlined below, pressors and IVF bolus to
   support BP. Mixed venous O2 sat in ED was 91%, so pRBCs were not
   administered, however hematocrit on admission
   was ~21, and pt was transfused. Hypothermia (current temp 95 with bear
   hugger), hyponatremia, hyperkalemia and hypoglycemia consistent with
   sepsis, but also concerning for adrenal insufficiency. Pt has not
   recently been on steroids and has no other RF for adrenal
   insufficiency.  BCx grew Clostridium Perfringens [**12-13**].  d/c
   cisatracurium. s/p CT abdomen on [**12-17**].
   - Continuing Zosyn & Micafungin per ID recs; dc
ed Vanc and clindamycin
   - Norepinephrine to titrate to MAP>60; vasopression dc
 pressors
   off
   - Monitor CVP (goal [**10-19**]) and SvO2 (goal>70%)
   - [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim test without appropriate increase in cortisol; start
   Hydrocort IV 50mg q6h today ([**12-18**])
   .
   Peritonitis: ?SBP but without positive cultures.  Abdominal pain,
   prominent neutrophilia on ascitic fluid diff (17,000 WBC, 87% neuts)
   and significant left-shift on CBC with diff (33% bands) in the setting
   of a history of variceal bleeding are all consistent with SBP. Normally
   would treat with ceftriaxone, but given additional concerns for
   pneumonia will treat with cipro, pip-tazo and vancomycin. Hepatobiliary
   sx recs ([**12-15**]): recommend re-tapping him today.  If his WBC is still
   very high, he may need to be explored.  WBC high but improved from
   prior, obtaining CT scan to further evaluate, as outlined above.
   - Continue Zosyn /Micafungin per ID recs
   - f/u GI/Liver recs
   - f/u general surgery recs
   .
   Dyspnea/Respiratory Failure: Pt was intubated in the ED given
   hypotension, concern for developing respiratory failure given
   tachypnea. ABG in MICU indicates elevated PaO2 on current ventilator
   settings.  The differential for the pt's dyspnea includes pneumonia,
   influenza, ascites or CHF. The pt had a left shift on CBC with diff and
   his girlfriend reported that he recently had a "respiratory infection"
   which raises concern for a post-viral pna or bacterial pna. Initial
   read of CXR raised concern for R LL infiltrate, however on final read
   there is no mention of an opacity. Tachypnea likely secondary to
   acidosis.  Also evidence of volume overload and CHF given edema, CXR
   consistent with fluid overload, and elevated CVP.
   - Consider Lasix diuresis tomorrow for volume overload, hold for now
   given had IV contrast dye load from CT scan on [**12-17**] so want to protect
   kidneys
   - Maintain on ventilator; Decrease FiO2, keep PEEP steady as given
   abdominal distention feel he needs this PEEP level.
   - ABG and lactate daily (lactate down-trending now)
   - Change from fentanyl and midazolam (concern with ARF that these
   medications are going to not be cleared for a while and may potentiate
   AMS as well as ileus); change to propofol
   - f/u sputum culture
   .
   Epistaxis:  ENT consulted, patient s/p bilateral packing.
   - f/u ENT recs
   - cont Epistaxis precautions
   .
   Acute Renal Failure:  Patient
s acute renal failure likely [**2-9**] sepsis,
   monitor. F/u renal recs.
   - Now resolved.
   - s/p IV contrast dye load on [**12-17**], Cr now rising.
   - consider small fluid bolus
   .
   Anemia: Pt's recent baseline hematocrit appears to be ~25-30, and was
   21 on admission. Pt was noted to be guaiac positive on exam in ED, and
   had frank blood in NGT. Suspect that pt has chronic macrocytic anemia
   secondary to liver disease, with superimposed acute blood loss anemia
   from variceal bleed or bleeding ulcer. No schistocytes on smear to
   indicate hemolysis, however INR more elevated than in the past, and
   thrombocytopenia is more pronounced. GI did an EGD to evaluate for UGIB
   cause and no bleeding source was found.  Pt was on pantoprazole bolus
   and octreotide gtt for likely variceal bleeding: d/c
d now as HCT
   stable.
   - Continue IV PPI [**Hospital1 **]
   - Daily coags and CBC; Transfuse as needed for falling Hct.
   .
   Hepatitis C Cirrhosis: MELD on admission was 27, discriminate function
   was 61. On exam pt is jaundiced. LFT's similar to prior LFT's with the
   exception of bili, which is markedly elevated at 18. Reportedly the pt
   stopped drinking EtOH in [**Month (only) 11**]. Serum EtOH was negative.
   - Hepatology will follow patient
   - Hold lactulose, rifaximin for now, restart when PO's okay
   - Hold nadolol for now given hypotension, pressor requirement
   .
   Less Active Issues
   .
   Thrombocytopenia: Currently plts are 34, which is below baseline.
   Suspect that thrombocytopenia is due to poor synthetic function in the
   setting of liver disease. Pt has chronic epistaxis. Hemolysis is less
   likely.  Smear showed: no schistocytes, a few large platelets but many
   small platelets.  Likely bone marrow difficulty with production at the
   same time as it tries to increase production in the setting of platelet
   destruction.
   - Trend plts daily
   - Avoid heparin products in the setting of plt<100, GIB
   .
   Non-anion gap Metabolic Acidosis: Resolved. pH on ABG 7.29. Pt has a
   normal anion gap in the setting of chronic hyponatremia. Suspect
   acidosis is secondary to lactic acidosis in the setting of sepsis,
   SBP.  s/p 2 units PRBC transfusion.
   - frequent ABG's
   - hold maintenance fluids to avoid worsening of acidosis
   - add on alk phos and CEA to ascitic fluid analysis given GI/Liver
   service's concern for perforation
   - f/u renal recs, likely no need for HD now
   .
   FEN: Hold on IVF today given peripheral edema, replete electrolytes
   Prophylaxis: pneumoboots
   Access: R and L 20-g PIVs, R triple-lumen IJ, a-line
   Code:  Full (discussed with girlfriend)
   Communication: [**Name (NI) **] GF and son
   Contact Info: Girlfriend [**Name (NI) 105**] [**Name (NI) 1309**]  cell: [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9699**] home: [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9771**]
   Son [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 5320**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9701**]
   .

Summary:

The patient is a 60-year-old male with a history of hepatitis C, cirrhosis, and esophageal varices admitted with dyspnea, diffuse abdominal pain, and a possibility of community-acquired pneumonia (CAP). He was intubated in the emergency department (ED) due to hypotension and concern for developing respiratory failure. Laboratory results show sepsis with a suspected source of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP), and the patient is being treated with antibiotics. He has acute renal failure, anemia, and thrombocytopenia, and is being monitored for these conditions. The patient also has chronic hepatitis C cirrhosis and is jaundiced. He is being treated with antiviral medications and is being monitored for liver function.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is already intubated and on mechanical ventilation, and there is a risk of further respiratory failure if the underlying condition is not addressed.
2. Sepsis: The patient has sepsis with a suspected source of SBP, and there is a risk of further deterioration if the infection is not adequately treated.
3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient has acute renal failure, and there is a risk of further deterioration if the underlying condition is not addressed.
4. Anemia: The patient has anemia, and there is a risk of further deterioration if the underlying condition is not addressed.
5. Thrombocytopenia: The patient has thrombocytopenia, and there is a risk of further deterioration if the underlying condition is not addressed.
6. Hepatitis C Cirrhosis: The patient has chronic hepatitis C cirrhosis, and there is a risk of further liver damage if the condition is not adequately treated.
7. Infection: The patient has a history of CAP, and there is a risk of further infection if the underlying condition is not adequately treated.
8. Fluid Overload: The patient has fluid overload, and there is a risk of further complications if the condition is not adequately treated.
9. Hypotension: The patient has hypotension, and there is a risk of further complications if the condition is not adequately treated.
10. Adrenal Insufficiency: The patient has suspected adrenal insufficiency, and there is a risk of further complications if the condition is not adequately treated.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust mechanical ventilation as needed.
2. Continue to treat the patient's sepsis with antibiotics and monitor for signs of improvement.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and adjust treatment as needed.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's anemia and thrombocytopenia and adjust treatment as needed.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's liver function and adjust treatment as needed.
6. Consider further imaging studies to evaluate the patient's abdominal pain and suspected SBP.
7. Consider further laboratory studies to evaluate the patient's anemia and thrombocytopenia.
8. Consider further treatment options for the patient's suspected adrenal insufficiency.
9. Continue to monitor the patient's fluid status and adjust treatment as needed.
10. Consider further treatment options for the patient's hypotension.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the information:

The patient is a 60-year-old man with HCV cirrhosis who was admitted to the ICU with C. perfringens peritonitis, septic shock, and respiratory failure. He is currently sedated and unable to provide a history. He has been receiving various medications, including antibiotics, antifungals, and vasopressors.

Physically, the patient is in no acute distress, with normal vital signs and a stable hemodynamic profile. He has a distended abdomen and peripheral edema, but his skin is warm. His neurologic examination is limited due to sedation.

Laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 11.9, hemoglobin of 9.6 g/dL, platelet count of 63, and creatinine of 1.5 mg/dL. His liver enzymes are elevated, and his bilirubin is high. He has acute kidney injury and is at risk for hepato-renal syndrome.

The patient's respiratory status is stable, with a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 133, but he is likely under-PEEP and will require an esophageal balloon study to optimize PEEP and decrease FiO2.

The patient's plan includes:

1. Septic shock management, including continued levophed requirement and hydrocortisone therapy.
2. Respiratory failure management, including an esophageal balloon study to optimize PEEP and decrease FiO2.
3. Cirrhosis management, including restarting lactulose therapy.
4. Acute renal failure management, including sending urine lytes and considering an albumin challenge.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Sepsis-related organ dysfunction, including respiratory, cardiovascular, or renal failure.
2. Hepato-renal syndrome, given the patient's high bilirubin and creatinine levels.
3. Respiratory failure, including the potential for ARDS.
4. Acute kidney injury, which can progress to chronic kidney disease.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding, given the patient's cirrhosis and portal hypertension.
6. Infection, including bacteremia or sepsis, given the patient's immunocompromised state.
7. Cardiovascular instability, including hypotension or cardiac arrest, given the patient's septic shock and cirrhosis.

Overall, the patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and management to prevent and treat potential complications.

   60 year old man with history of hepatitis C (s/p interferon rx with no
   response), cirrhosis, esophageal varices and hyponatremia admitted with
   dyspnea and diffuse abdominal pain, found to have peritonitis as well
   as a possibility of CAP.
   .
   Sepsis: Suspect sepsis is due to SBP as below, also possibly due to
   pna. Will treat with abx as outlined below, pressors and IVF bolus to
   support BP. Mixed venous O2 sat in ED was 91%, so pRBCs were not
   administered, however hematocrit on admission
   was ~21, and pt was transfused. Hypothermia (current temp 95 with bear
   hugger), hyponatremia, hyperkalemia and hypoglycemia consistent with
   sepsis, but also concerning for adrenal insufficiency. Pt has not
   recently been on steroids and has no other RF for adrenal
   insufficiency.  BCx grew Clostridium Perfringens [**12-13**].  d/c
   cisatracurium. s/p CT abdomen on [**12-17**].
   - Continuing Zosyn & Micafungin per ID recs; dc
ed Vanc and clindamycin
   - Norepinephrine to titrate to MAP>60; vasopression dc
 pressors
   off
   - Monitor CVP (goal [**10-19**]) and SvO2 (goal>70%)
   - [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim test without appropriate increase in cortisol; start
   Hydrocort IV 50mg q6h today ([**12-18**])
   .
   Peritonitis: ?SBP but without positive cultures.  Abdominal pain,
   prominent neutrophilia on ascitic fluid diff (17,000 WBC, 87% neuts)
   and significant left-shift on CBC with diff (33% bands) in the setting
   of a history of variceal bleeding are all consistent with SBP. Normally
   would treat with ceftriaxone, but given additional concerns for
   pneumonia will treat with cipro, pip-tazo and vancomycin. Hepatobiliary
   sx recs ([**12-15**]): recommend re-tapping him today.  If his WBC is still
   very high, he may need to be explored.  WBC high but improved from
   prior, obtaining CT scan to further evaluate, as outlined above.
   - Continue Zosyn /Micafungin per ID recs
   - f/u GI/Liver recs
   - f/u general surgery recs
   .
   Dyspnea/Respiratory Failure: Pt was intubated in the ED given
   hypotension, concern for developing respiratory failure given
   tachypnea. ABG in MICU indicates elevated PaO2 on current ventilator
   settings.  The differential for the pt's dyspnea includes pneumonia,
   influenza, ascites or CHF. The pt had a left shift on CBC with diff and
   his girlfriend reported that he recently had a "respiratory infection"
   which raises concern for a post-viral pna or bacterial pna. Initial
   read of CXR raised concern for R LL infiltrate, however on final read
   there is no mention of an opacity. Tachypnea likely secondary to
   acidosis.  Also evidence of volume overload and CHF given edema, CXR
   consistent with fluid overload, and elevated CVP.
   - hold for diuresis for now given had IV contrast dye load from CT scan
   on [**12-17**] and has incr Cr over last 2 days
   -  Maintain on ventilator; Decrease FiO2, try to increase PEEP as given
   abdominal distention feel he needs a lot of PEEP.
   - Place esophageal balloon
   - ABG and lactate daily (lactate down-trending now)
   - All sedation off x 24 hours on [**12-19**]
   - f/u sputum culture
   .
   Acute Renal Failure:  Patient initially had elevated Cr, thought to be
   due to sepsis which resolved).  Pt
s creatinine has been rising again x
   2 days (during this hospitalization, Cr 1.7 -> 0.8 -> today 1.5
   [**12-19**]).  ARF most likely due to aggressive diuresis in last several
   days plus IV contrast load for CT abd.  However, hepatorenal syndrome
   is also a possibility.
   - F/u renal/hepatology recs.
   - will give IV albumin 1g/kg.
   - monitor UOP closely
   .
   Altered mental status: Pt is still with decreased mental status despite
   being off of sedation x 1 day on [**12-19**]. Neurologic exam difficult, but
   no obvious deficit. The most likely etiology at this point is stage 4
   hepatic encephalopathy, given patient
s severe liver disease and rising
   bilirubin.
   - Restart lactulose today.  Titrate to 3 BMs daily.
   - Can add back Rifaxamin if no improvement with lactulose alone.
   - Can consider head CT, and additional AMS w/u if no improvement with
   tx of hepatic encephalopathy.
   .
   Epistaxis:  ENT consulted, patient s/p bilateral packing.
   - f/u ENT recs
   - cont Epistaxis precautions
   .
   Anemia: Pt's recent baseline hematocrit appears to be ~25-30, and was
   21 on admission. Pt was noted to be guaiac positive on exam in ED, and
   had frank blood in NGT. Suspect that pt has chronic macrocytic anemia
   secondary to liver disease, with superimposed acute blood loss anemia
   from variceal bleed or bleeding ulcer. No schistocytes on smear to
   indicate hemolysis, however INR more elevated than in the past, and
   thrombocytopenia is more pronounced. GI did an EGD to evaluate for UGIB
   cause and no bleeding source was found.  Pt was on pantoprazole bolus
   and octreotide gtt for likely variceal bleeding: d/c
d now as HCT
   stable.
   - Continue IV PPI [**Hospital1 **]
   - Daily coags and CBC; Transfuse as needed for falling Hct.
   .
   Hepatitis C Cirrhosis: MELD on admission was 27, discriminate function
   was 61. On exam pt is jaundiced. LFT's similar to prior LFT's with the
   exception of bili, which is markedly elevated at 18. Reportedly the pt
   stopped drinking EtOH in [**Month (only) 11**]. Serum EtOH was negative.
   - F/u Hepatology recs
   - Restarting lactulose today
   - Hold nadolol for now given hypotension, pressor requirement
   .
   Less Active Issues
   .
   Thrombocytopenia: Currently plts are 34, which is below baseline.
   Suspect that thrombocytopenia is due to poor synthetic function in the
   setting of liver disease. Pt has chronic epistaxis. Hemolysis is less
   likely.  Smear showed: no schistocytes, a few large platelets but many
   small platelets.  Likely bone marrow difficulty with production at the
   same time as it tries to increase production in the setting of platelet
   destruction.
   - Trend plts daily
   - Avoid heparin products in the setting of plt<100, GIB
   .
   Non-anion gap Metabolic Acidosis: Resolved. pH on ABG 7.29. Pt has a
   normal anion gap in the setting of chronic hyponatremia. Suspect
   acidosis is secondary to lactic acidosis in the setting of sepsis,
   SBP.  s/p 2 units PRBC transfusion.
   - frequent ABG's
   - hold maintenance fluids to avoid worsening of acidosis
   - add on alk phos and CEA to ascitic fluid analysis given GI/Liver
   service's concern for perforation
   - f/u renal recs, likely no need for HD now
   .
   FEN: Hold on IVF today given peripheral edema, replete electrolytes

Based on the patient's progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is intubated and on ventilator support, which increases the risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), lung injury, and respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient has sepsis with a high suspicion of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP), which can lead to multi-organ dysfunction, including respiratory, cardiovascular, and renal failure.
3. Hepatorenal Syndrome: The patient has cirrhosis, and the recent diuresis and IV contrast load may have precipitated hepatorenal syndrome, which can lead to acute kidney injury and worsening liver function.
4. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine levels have been rising, and the recent diuresis and IV contrast load may have contributed to acute kidney injury.
5. Altered Mental Status: The patient has decreased mental status, which may be due to stage 4 hepatic encephalopathy, sepsis, or other underlying conditions.
6. Anemia: The patient has chronic macrocytic anemia secondary to liver disease, with superimposed acute blood loss anemia from variceal bleed or bleeding ulcer.
7. Thrombocytopenia: The patient has thrombocytopenia, which may be due to poor synthetic function in the setting of liver disease, and may increase the risk of bleeding complications.
8. Non-anion gap Metabolic Acidosis: The patient has resolved non-anion gap metabolic acidosis, but may be at risk of developing lactic acidosis or other metabolic acidosis in the setting of sepsis and liver disease.
9. Fluid Overload: The patient has evidence of fluid overload, including peripheral edema, ascites, and elevated CVP, which may increase the risk of respiratory and cardiovascular complications.
10. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient has a history of variceal bleed and bleeding ulcer, which may increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding complications.

The patient's condition is complex, and it is essential to closely monitor their progress and adjust treatment accordingly to prevent or mitigate these potential complications.

   60 year old man with history of hepatitis C (s/p interferon rx with no
   response), cirrhosis, esophageal varices and hyponatremia admitted with
   dyspnea and diffuse abdominal pain, found to have peritonitis as well
   as a possibility of CAP.
   .
   Sepsis: Suspect sepsis is due to SBP as below, also possibly due to
   pna. Will treat with abx as outlined below, pressors and IVF bolus to
   support BP. Mixed venous O2 sat in ED was 91%, so pRBCs were not
   administered, however hematocrit on admission
   was ~21, and pt was transfused. Hypothermia (current temp 95 with bear
   hugger), hyponatremia, hyperkalemia and hypoglycemia consistent with
   sepsis, but also concerning for adrenal insufficiency. Pt has not
   recently been on steroids and has no other RF for adrenal
   insufficiency.  BCx grew Clostridium Perfringens [**12-13**].  d/c
   cisatracurium. s/p CT abdomen on [**12-17**].
   - Continuing Zosyn per ID recs; dc
ed Vanc, Clindamycin, Micafungin
   - Attempt to wean Norepinephrine to titrate to MAP>60; vasopression
   dc
   - Start Midodrine per ID recs to help wean off pressors
   - Continue Octreotide
   - [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim test without appropriate increase in cortisol; started
   Hydrocort IV 50mg q6h today ([**12-18**]).  Wean [**12-20**] to Hydrocort IV 25mg
   q6h.
   - Monitor CVP (goal [**10-19**])
   .
   Peritonitis: ?SBP but without positive cultures.  Abdominal pain,
   prominent neutrophilia on ascitic fluid diff (17,000 WBC, 87% neuts)
   and significant left-shift on CBC with diff (33% bands) in the setting
   of a history of variceal bleeding are all consistent with SBP. Normally
   would treat with ceftriaxone, but given additional concerns for
   pneumonia will treat with cipro, pip-tazo and vancomycin. Hepatobiliary
   sx recs ([**12-15**]): recommend re-tapping him today.  If his WBC is still
   very high, he may need to be explored.  WBC high but improved from
   prior, obtaining CT scan to further evaluate, as outlined above.
   - Continue Zosyn as above
   - f/u GI/Liver recs
   - f/u ID recs
   - f/u transplant surgery recs
   - Consider repeat paracentesis to trend WBC count and abdominal
   pressure preventing lung expansion
   .
   Dyspnea/Respiratory Failure: Pt was intubated in the ED given
   hypotension, concern for developing respiratory failure given
   tachypnea. ABG in MICU indicates elevated PaO2 on current ventilator
   settings.  The differential for the pt's dyspnea includes pneumonia,
   influenza, ascites or CHF. The pt had a left shift on CBC with diff and
   his girlfriend reported that he recently had a "respiratory infection"
   which raises concern for a post-viral pna or bacterial pna. Initial
   read of CXR raised concern for R LL infiltrate, however on final read
   there is no mention of an opacity. Tachypnea likely secondary to
   acidosis.  Also evidence of volume overload and CHF given edema, CXR
   consistent with fluid overload, and elevated CVP.
   -  Maintain on ventilator; Decrease FiO2 from 50% to 40% today.
   Increased PEEP [**12-19**] given abdominal distention causing likely lung
   compression.
   - Esophageal balloon in place
   - ABG and lactate daily (lactate down-trending now)
   - All sedation off on [**12-19**]
   - f/u sputum culture
   - hold for diuresis for now given had IV contrast dye load from CT scan
   on [**12-17**] and has incr Cr over last 2 days
   .
   Acute Renal Failure:  Patient initially had elevated Cr, thought to be
   due to sepsis which resolved).  Pt
s creatinine has been rising again x
   2 days (during this hospitalization, Cr 1.7 -> 0.8 -> today 1.5
   [**12-19**]).  ARF most likely due to aggressive diuresis in last several
   days plus IV contrast load for CT abd.  However, hepatorenal syndrome
   is also a possibility, given Midodrine, Octreotide, Albumin.
   - F/u renal recs.
   - f/u hepatology recs
   - IVF 1L D5W today for free water
   - IV albumin 50g if UOP decreases
   - monitor UOP closely
   .
   Altered mental status: Pt is still with decreased mental status despite
   being off of sedation x 1 day on [**12-19**]. Neurologic exam difficult, but
   no obvious deficit. The most likely etiology at this point is stage 4
   hepatic encephalopathy, given patient
s severe liver disease and rising
   bilirubin.
   - Titrate up Lactulose to 3 BMs daily.
   - Re-start Rifaxamin
   - Can consider head CT, and additional AMS w/u if no improvement with
   tx of hepatic encephalopathy.
   .
   Epistaxis:  ENT consulted, patient s/p bilateral packing.
   - f/u ENT recs
   - cont Epistaxis precautions
   .
   Anemia: Pt's recent baseline hematocrit appears to be ~25-30, and was
   21 on admission. Pt was noted to be guaiac positive on exam in ED, and
   had frank blood in NGT. Suspect that pt has chronic macrocytic anemia
   secondary to liver disease, with superimposed acute blood loss anemia
   from variceal bleed or bleeding ulcer. No schistocytes on smear to
   indicate hemolysis, however INR more elevated than in the past, and
   thrombocytopenia is more pronounced. GI did an EGD to evaluate for UGIB
   cause and no bleeding source was found.  Pt was on pantoprazole bolus
   and octreotide gtt for likely variceal bleeding: d/c
d now as HCT
   stable.
   - Continue IV PPI [**Hospital1 **]
   - [**Hospital1 **] coags and CBC; Transfuse as needed for falling Hct.
   - 2 units FFP prior to any procedures (paracentesis)
   .
   Hepatitis C Cirrhosis: MELD on admission was 27, discriminate function
   was 61. On exam pt is jaundiced. LFT's similar to prior LFT's with the
   exception of bili, which is markedly elevated at 18. Reportedly the pt
   stopped drinking EtOH in [**Month (only) 11**]. Serum EtOH was negative.
   - F/u Hepatology recs
   - lactulose and Rifaximin
   - Hold nadolol for now given hypotension, pressor requirement
   .
   Less Active Issues
   .
   Thrombocytopenia: Currently plts are 34, which is below baseline.
   Suspect that thrombocytopenia is due to poor synthetic function in the
   setting of liver disease. Pt has chronic epistaxis. Hemolysis is less
   likely.  Smear showed: no schistocytes, a few large platelets but many

   - Trend plts daily
   - Avoid heparin products in the setting of plt<100, GIB

   Non-anion gap Metabolic Acidosis: Resolved. pH on ABG 7.29. Pt has a
   normal anion gap in the setting of chronic hyponatremia. Suspect
   acidosis is secondary to lactic acidosis in the setting of sepsis,

   - frequent ABG's
   - hold maintenance fluids to avoid worsening of acidosis

   sepsis, but also concerning for adrenal insufficiency. Pt has not
   recently been on steroids and has no other RF for adrenal
   insufficiency.  BCx grew Clostridium Perfringens [**12-13**].  d/c
   cisatracurium. s/p CT abdomen on [**12-17**].
   - Continuing Zosyn per ID recs; dc
ed Vanc, Clindamycin, Micafungin
   - Attempt to wean Norepinephrine to titrate to MAP>60; vasopression
   dc
   - Start Midodrine per ID recs to help wean off pressors
   - Continue Octreotide
   - [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim test without appropriate increase in cortisol; started
   Hydrocort IV 50mg q6h today ([**12-18**]).  Wean [**12-20**] to Hydrocort IV 25mg
   q6h.
   - Monitor CVP (goal [**10-19**])
   .
   Peritonitis: ?SBP but without positive cultures.  Abdominal pain,
   prominent neutrophilia on ascitic fluid diff (17,000 WBC, 87% neuts)
   and significant left-shift on CBC with diff (33% bands) in the setting
   of a history of variceal bleeding are all consistent with SBP. Normally
   would treat with ceftriaxone, but given additional concerns for
   pneumonia will treat with cipro, pip-tazo and vancomycin. Hepatobiliary
   sx recs ([**12-15**]): recommend re-tapping him today.  If his WBC is still
   very high, he may need to be explored.  WBC high but improved from
   prior, obtaining CT scan to further evaluate, as outlined above.
   - Continue Zosyn as above
   - f/u GI/Liver recs
   - f/u ID recs
   - f/u transplant surgery recs
   - Consider repeat paracentesis to trend WBC count and abdominal
   pressure preventing lung expansion
   .
   Dyspnea/Respiratory Failure: Pt was intubated in the ED given
   hypotension, concern for developing respiratory failure given
   tachypnea. ABG in MICU indicates elevated PaO2 on current ventilator
   settings.  The differential for the pt's dyspnea includes pneumonia,
   influenza, ascites or CHF. The pt had a left shift on CBC with diff and
   his girlfriend reported that he recently had a "respiratory infection"
   which raises concern for a post-viral pna or bacterial pna. Initial
   read of CXR raised concern for R LL infiltrate, however on final read
   there is no mention of an opacity. Tachypnea likely secondary to
   acidosis.  Also evidence of volume overload and CHF given edema, CXR
   consistent with fluid overload, and elevated CVP.
   -  Maintain on ventilator; Decrease FiO2 from 50% to 40% today.
   Increased PEEP [**12-19**] given abdominal distention causing likely lung
   compression.
   - Esophageal balloon in place
   - ABG and lactate daily (lactate down-trending now)
   - All sedation off on [**12-19**]
   - f/u sputum culture
   - hold for diuresis for now given had IV contrast dye load from CT scan
   on [**12-17**] and has incr Cr over last 2 days
   .
   Acute Renal Failure:  Patient initially had elevated Cr, thought to be
   due to sepsis which resolved).  Pt
s creatinine has been rising again x
   2 days (during this hospitalization, Cr 1.7 -> 0.8 -> today 1.5
   [**12-19**]).  ARF most likely due to aggressive diuresis in last several
   days plus IV contrast load for CT abd.  However, hepatorenal syndrome
   is also a possibility, given Midodrine, Octreotide, Albumin.
   - F/u renal recs.
   - f/u hepatology recs
   - IVF 1L D5W today for free water
   - IV albumin 50g if UOP decreases
   - monitor UOP closely
   .
   Altered mental status: Pt is still with decreased mental status despite
   being off of sedation x 1 day on [**12-19**]. Neurologic exam difficult, but
   no obvious deficit. The most likely etiology at this point is stage 4
   hepatic encephalopathy, given patient
s severe liver disease and rising
   bilirubin.
   - Titrate up Lactulose to 3 BMs daily.
   - Re-start Rifaxamin
   - Can consider head CT, and additional AMS w/u if no improvement with
   tx of hepatic encephalopathy.
   .
   Epistaxis:  ENT consulted, patient s/p bilateral packing.
   - f/u ENT recs
   - cont Epistaxis precautions
   .
   Anemia: Pt's recent baseline hematocrit appears to be ~25-30, and was
   21 on admission. Pt was noted to be guaiac positive on exam in ED, and
   had frank blood in NGT. Suspect that pt has chronic macrocytic anemia
   secondary to liver disease, with superimposed acute blood loss anemia
   from variceal bleed or bleeding ulcer. No schistocytes on smear to
   indicate hemolysis, however INR more elevated than in the past, and
   thrombocytopenia is more pronounced. GI did an EGD to evaluate for UGIB
   cause and no bleeding source was found.  Pt was on pantoprazole bolus
   and octreotide gtt for likely variceal bleeding: d/c
d now as HCT
   stable.
   - Continue IV PPI [**Hospital1 **]
   - [**Hospital1 **] coags and CBC; Transfuse as needed for falling Hct.
   - 2 units FFP prior to any procedures (paracentesis)
   .
   Hepatitis C Cirrhosis: MELD on admission was 27, discriminate function
   was 61. On exam pt is jaundiced. LFT's similar to prior LFT's with the
   exception of bili, which is markedly elevated at 18. Reportedly the pt
   stopped drinking EtOH in [**Month (only) 11**]. Serum EtOH was negative.
   - F/u Hepatology recs
   - lactulose and Rifaximin
   - Hold nadolol for now given hypotension, pressor requirement
   .
   Less Active Issues
   .
   Thrombocytopenia: Currently plts are 34, which is below baseline.
   Suspect that thrombocytopenia is due to poor synthetic function in the
   setting of liver disease. Pt has chronic epistaxis. Hemolysis is less
   likely.  Smear showed: no schistocytes, a few large platelets but many
   small platelets.  Likely bone marrow difficulty with production at the
   same time as it tries to increase production in the setting of platelet
   destruction.
   - Trend plts daily
   - Avoid heparin products in the setting of plt<100, GIB
   .
   Non-anion gap Metabolic Acidosis: Resolved. pH on ABG 7.29. Pt has a
   normal anion gap in the setting of chronic hyponatremia. Suspect
   acidosis is secondary to lactic acidosis in the setting of sepsis,
   SBP.  s/p 2 units PRBC transfusion.
   - frequent ABG's
   - hold maintenance fluids to avoid worsening of acidosis
   - add on alk phos and CEA to ascitic fluid analysis given GI/Liver
   service's concern for perforation
   - f/u renal recs, likely no need for HD now
   .
   FEN: Hold on IVF today given peripheral edema, replete electrolytes
   Prophylaxis: pneumoboots
   Access: R and L 20-g PIVs, R triple-lumen IJ, a-line
   Code:  Full (discussed with girlfriend)
   Communication: [**Name (NI) **] GF and son
   Contact Info: Girlfriend [**Name (NI) 105**] [**Name (NI) 1309**]  cell: [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9699**] home: [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9771**]
   Son [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 5320**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9701**]
   .
   Disposition: pending clinical improvement, ICU for now
   ICU Care

Summary:

The patient is a 60-year-old man with a history of hepatitis C cirrhosis, esophageal varices, and hyponatremia, admitted with dyspnea and diffuse abdominal pain. He was found to have peritonitis and a possibility of CAP. He developed sepsis, acute renal failure, altered mental status, and respiratory failure, requiring intubation and mechanical ventilation. He also has chronic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and non-anion gap metabolic acidosis.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Hepatorenal syndrome: The patient's increasing creatinine levels and urine sodium levels < 10 mmol/L suggest a possible diagnosis of hepatorenal syndrome, which is a common complication of liver cirrhosis.
2. Sepsis: The patient's elevated lactate levels and WBC count suggest ongoing sepsis, which may lead to further organ dysfunction and mortality.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if not adequately managed, leading to further hypoxia and respiratory acidosis.
4. Acute kidney injury: The patient's increasing creatinine levels and oliguria suggest acute kidney injury, which may progress to chronic kidney disease.
5. Hepatic encephalopathy: The patient's altered mental status and elevated bilirubin levels suggest a possible diagnosis of hepatic encephalopathy, which may worsen if not adequately managed.
6. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia may worsen if not adequately managed, leading to bleeding complications.
7. Non-anion gap metabolic acidosis: The patient's metabolic acidosis may worsen if not adequately managed, leading to further organ dysfunction and mortality.

Assessment and Plan:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status.
2. Manage the patient's sepsis with antibiotics and supportive care.
3. Optimize the patient's fluid management to prevent further fluid overload and worsening of renal function.
4. Consider the patient for liver transplantation if his condition does not improve.
5. Monitor the patient's mental status and adjust his treatment plan accordingly.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's platelet count and bleeding risk.
7. Consider the patient for further diagnostic testing, such as a head CT, to evaluate his altered mental status.

Recommendations:

1. Consult with the patient's primary care physician to discuss his treatment plan and potential complications.
2. Consider the patient for admission to a liver transplant center if his condition does not improve.
3. Monitor the patient's laboratory results and adjust his treatment plan accordingly.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and clinical status.
5. Consider the patient for further diagnostic testing, such as a head CT, to evaluate his altered mental status.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's platelet count and bleeding risk.
7. Consider the patient for further treatment options, such as liver transplantation, if his condition does not improve.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 37.1°C (98.7°F)
* Heart rate: 86 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 113/55 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 15 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 96%
* Central venous pressure: 16 mmHg

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin: 8.1 g/dL
* White blood cell count: 10.5 K/uL
* Platelet count: 38 K/uL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 27 mEq/L
* Creatinine: 1.2 mg/dL
* Sodium: 141 mEq/L
* Potassium: 4.4 mEq/L
* Chloride: 102 mEq/L
* Calcium: 10.1 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.9 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 6.5 mg/dL

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Respiratory failure, acute
* Sepsis without organ dysfunction
* Peritonitis, spontaneous bacterial (SBP)
* Anemia, chronic
* Anemia, acute, secondary to blood loss (hemorrhage, bleeding)
* Thrombocytopenia, chronic
* Cirrhosis of the liver, other
* Hepatitis, other
* Acidosis, metabolic

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continued mechanical ventilation
* Antibiotics for sepsis
* Supportive care for respiratory failure
* Management of anemia and thrombocytopenia
* Monitoring of liver function and acid-base status

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Progressive respiratory failure and hypoxia
* Sepsis-induced multi-organ dysfunction
* Hemorrhagic complications from thrombocytopenia
* Hepatic failure and encephalopathy
* Metabolic acidosis and electrolyte imbalance
* Infection-related complications, such as pneumonia or sepsis

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 60-year-old male with a complex medical condition, including:

1. Peritonitis due to Clostridium perfringens (C. perfringens) sepsis, which has progressed to septic shock and respiratory failure.
2. Chronic and acute anemia secondary to blood loss and chronic liver disease (cirrhosis).
3. Thrombocytopenia (low platelet count) due to chronic liver disease.
4. Cirrhosis of the liver, likely due to hepatitis C (HCV).
5. Hepatitis, possibly related to HCV.
6. Metabolic acidosis, which may be related to the patient's liver disease and sepsis.

The patient is receiving multiple medications, including antibiotics, antifungals, and vasopressors to manage his septic shock. He is also receiving mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy to support his respiratory function.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Further deterioration of respiratory function, potentially leading to acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
2. Worsening of liver function, potentially leading to hepatic encephalopathy, coagulopathy, or gastrointestinal bleeding.
3. Development of acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease due to sepsis, liver disease, or nephrotoxic medications.
4. Increased risk of bleeding due to thrombocytopenia and coagulopathy.
5. Development of secondary infections, such as pneumonia or urinary tract infections, which can further complicate the patient's condition.
6. Potential for cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or cardiac arrest, due to sepsis and liver disease.
7. Increased risk of nosocomial infections, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), due to the patient's prolonged hospitalization and mechanical ventilation.

Given the patient's complex medical condition and the potential complications that can arise, it is essential to continue monitoring his vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status closely and adjust his treatment plan accordingly.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 60-year-old man with a complex medical condition, including:

1. C. perfringens peritonitis, which is a life-threatening infection of the peritoneum.
2. Septic shock, which is a severe response to the infection, characterized by low blood pressure, rapid heart rate, and inadequate organ perfusion.
3. Respiratory failure, requiring mechanical ventilation to support his breathing.
4. Anemia, both chronic and acute, likely secondary to blood loss and ongoing bleeding.
5. Thrombocytopenia, or low platelet count, which increases the risk of bleeding.
6. Cirrhosis of the liver, which is a chronic condition characterized by scarring and damage to the liver tissue.
7. Hepatitis, which is an inflammation of the liver, likely secondary to the patient's underlying liver disease.
8. Acidosis, a metabolic disorder characterized by an imbalance of acid-base levels in the blood.

The patient is receiving multiple medications to manage his condition, including antibiotics, vasopressors, and respiratory support. He is also receiving nutritional support, including parenteral nutrition, and has a central venous catheter in place for medication administration and laboratory testing.

The patient's laboratory results show evidence of ongoing bleeding, with a low platelet count and elevated liver enzymes. His kidney function is also impaired, with elevated creatinine levels and a rising trend.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a blood pressure of 113/55 mmHg, heart rate of 86 beats per minute, and respiratory rate of 15 breaths per minute. His oxygen saturation is 96% on a ventilator.

The patient's physical examination reveals no acute distress, with symmetric breath sounds and clear lung fields. His abdomen is distended, and he has bilateral lower extremity edema.

The patient's medical history is significant for chronic liver disease, including cirrhosis and hepatitis. He has a history of bleeding, including a recent episode of gastrointestinal bleeding.

The patient's condition is critical, and he requires close monitoring and management in the intensive care unit. The patient's code status is full code, indicating that he is willing to receive all available life-sustaining treatments.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Sepsis-related organ dysfunction, including acute kidney injury, liver failure, and respiratory failure.
2. Bleeding complications, including gastrointestinal bleeding, intracranial hemorrhage, and pulmonary hemorrhage.
3. Respiratory failure, including ventilator-associated pneumonia and acute respiratory distress syndrome.
4. Metabolic acidosis, which can lead to cardiac arrhythmias, muscle weakness, and respiratory failure.
5. Hepatic encephalopathy, which can cause confusion, disorientation, and coma.
6. Renal failure, which can require dialysis and increase the risk of complications.
7. Infection, including catheter-related bloodstream infections and pneumonia.

In summary, the patient is a critically ill individual with a complex medical condition requiring close monitoring and management in the intensive care unit. He requires ongoing support with antibiotics, vasopressors, and respiratory therapy to manage his septic shock, respiratory failure, and bleeding complications.
